description: This polar sundial is on Pauls Walk by the north end of the Millennium bridge.  It is publicly accessible and gets sunshine all day.  There will be talks at the sudial every 15 minutes between 11.45 and 2 pm each day

factsheet.heading: The sundial
paragraphs:
This sundial is located on Pauls Walk on the north side of the Thames, 75 yards upstream from the Millennium Bridge
It is of a very unusual design.  It is a polar  sundial, in which the gnomon (which casts the shadow) is pointing to the polestar, and the dial plate (which has the hour markings) is parallel to it.  The dial was commissioned by the Worshipful Company of Tylers and Bricklayers to commemorate the Millennium, was built by the Royal Enginners, and was opened by the Lord Mayor in November 1999.  The sundial stands on a plinth of exactly 2000 bricks, one for each year of the two millennia.

factsheet.heading: The Open ouse event
paragraphs:
The sundial was designed by Piers Nicholson who, with colleagues from the British Sundial Society will be present between 1 and 3 pm  at the sundial on the following dates: (tba)
There will be a short talk every 15 minutes throughout the open period on these dates.  The talk will cover the genesis of this sundial, how to read the time from it, and sources of information about sundials.  It will be followed by 5 minutes for questions, and then the cycle will be repeated every quarter-hour.
Please also visit the Fleet Street Heritage Sundial at the corner of Fleet Street and Bouverie Street, where similar talks will be given between 9 and 11 each day.

factsheet.heading: If you can't come to the talk
paragraphs: The sundial is publicly accessible 24/7, so if you cannot come for the talk, please visit at another time convenient to you.  There is a plaque beside the sundial which explains in  detail how it works.  There is more information on the website https://nicholson.sundials.co/t&b.html
